conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the forces acting on the hemispherical bodies A, B, and C.
Body A has mass m and is resting on a rough surface.
Body B has mass 2m and is also resting on a rough surface.
Body C has mass m and is placed between A and B with a smooth outer surface.

premise: Body A has mass m and is resting on a rough surface.
conclusion: The forces acting on body A are gravitational force mg downward, normal force F upward from the ground, and frictional force f opposing any horizontal motion.

premise: Body B has mass 2m and is also resting on a rough surface.
conclusion: The forces acting on body B are gravitational force 2mg downward, normal force F_B upward from the ground, and frictional force f_B opposing any horizontal motion.

premise: Body C has mass m and is placed between A and B with a smooth outer surface.
conclusion: The forces acting on body C are gravitational force mg downward and two normal forces N from bodies A and B acting at an angle.
Since all bodies are at rest, the net force in both horizontal and vertical directions must be zero.

premise: The forces acting on body A are gravitational force mg downward, normal force F upward from the ground, and frictional force f opposing any horizontal motion.
conclusion: For body A: F = mg + N cos(theta), where theta is the angle between the vertical and the line of action of the normal force N.

premise: The forces acting on body B are gravitational force 2mg downward, normal force F_B upward from the ground, and frictional force f_B opposing any horizontal motion.
conclusion: For body B: F_B = 2mg + N cos(theta).

premise: The forces acting on body C are gravitational force mg downward and two normal forces N from bodies A and B acting at an angle.
conclusion: For body C: The vertical component of the normal forces from A and B must balance the gravitational force mg. Therefore, 2N cos(theta) = mg.

premise: The forces acting on body A are gravitational force mg downward, normal force F upward from the ground, and frictional force f opposing any horizontal motion.
conclusion: For body A: The frictional force f must balance the horizontal component of the normal force N. Therefore, f = N sin(theta).

premise: The forces acting on body B are gravitational force 2mg downward, normal force F_B upward from the ground, and frictional force f_B opposing any horizontal motion.
conclusion: For body B: The frictional force f_B must balance the horizontal component of the normal force N. Therefore, f_B = N sin(theta).
Since body C is symmetrical and placed between A and B, the angle theta can be determined using geometry.
